subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] How I spend every weekend! [2 Attachments]
author: Zack Widup
full_text:
I have had great luck with the Datak chemicals up to about 4 months ago. The
ER-71 photoresist and ER-8 developer did a fine job for boards I made
including some millimeter-wave circuits on 5 mil thick Duroid that required
tolerances to a couple thousandths of an inch.

However, either the quality control of Datak photoresist has gone to hell or
they changed it, because I've had a lot of trouble getting even coats of it
on the boards with the newer ER-71. I asked them about it with no replies.

I've gotten lots of G-10/FR-4 board material of all sizes and thicknesses at
hamfests. It's usually pretty cheap there. A couple years ago I got some
2-ft square pieces of .062 inch thick G-10, double-sided copper, for $3
apiece.

You can cut grooves in the copper with an X-Acto knife, making individual
pads on the board that work quite well. I've done that too.

Zack


On Mon, Apr 13, 2009 at 9:43 AM, Frank Sumption
<purplealiengirl@...>wrote:

>   [Attachment(s) <#1209fefe65dd6616_TopText> from Frank Sumption included
> below]
>
>  I really need to get a life! I never did have much luck trying to etch
> boards, probably due to lack of a proper etching tank, but I just use a home
> made wood chissle made out of a ground down saber saw blade to cut the
> traces, or pads. This is actually faster than hand wiring a perf board--and
> more reliable! I do use a drill press, and little micro drills, and if I
> have enough area around a pad I use a dremel tool. This time I've leaving
> out IC sockets, except for the function generator chip. My mother always
> said I had the patience of a saint!
>
>  BTW, the copper board is from Radio Shack, seems like RS is the number one
> supplier of EVP supplies.
>
>  F-S
>  
>
